required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Urinary Excretion of Anthocyanins During Long Term Blueberry Feeding
clinical_study.official_title: Urinary Excretion of Anthocyanins During Long Term Blueberry Feeding

lead_sponsor.agency: Atlantic Food and Horticulture Research Center

clinical_study.source: Atlantic Food and Horticulture Research Center

brief_summary.textblock: Essentially all of the published data on anthocyanin absorption in humans are from short term studies - a few days or less, most typically 24 h. However human studies demonstrating clinical effects are typically conducted for several weeks or even months. To examine how anthocyanin absorption and metabolism may be affected this study will examine urinary excretion of anthocyanins over one month, followed by a one week washout, and then one more dose of blueberry juice.

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Bio-availability Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Basic Science

primary_outcome.measure: Anthocyanins and Phase 2 anthocyanin conjugates in urine

secondary_outcome.measure: White blood cell gene expression at start and end of study

arm_group.description: Maintain anthocyanin-free diet throughout study. Day 1 to day 30, consume daily 250 ml single strength blueberry juice containing 229 mg anthocyanins, taken either as 1 morning dose or 1/3 dose morning, 1/3 mid-day and 1/3 evening. At d 31-38 continue anthocyanin-free diet. On d 39 consume daily dose.

intervention.other_name: Single strength wild blueberry juice, commercially prepared.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Provided written consent (see: Information and Consent Form)
- Fluent in English
- Complete a confidential medical questionnaire (Appendix 6)
- Able and willing to abide by the dietary restrictions as described
- Able and willing to abide by the urine collection protocols as described
Exclusion Criteria:
- No written consent
- No confidential medical questionnaire
- Unable to comply with diet restrictions and other study requirements
